Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Transforming Undergraduate Physical Chemistry Education using a Context Rich Pedagogy to Teach Kinetics, Quantum Mechanics, and Spectroscopy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The collaborative project between Knox College and Grinnell College is developing adaptable laboratory and curricular materials for an advanced chemistry course using a context-rich pedagogical approach. The project is (1) introducing modular spectroscopic instrumentation and computational techniques into the physical chemistry curriculum, (2) guiding the students in developing skills that will let them apply their knowledge of physical chemistry concepts to interdisciplinary applications, (3) assessing the impact of contextualized laboratory experiments to student comprehension and attitudes, and (4) disseminating the materials and assessment findings to the community.

The project is building on a prior NSF funded project, the Physical Chemistry with a Purpose module series (DUE 0340873) by developing complementary laboratory exercise that introduce students to selected spectroscopic techniques and computational methods used in modern research. Experiments are being developed featuring some combination of Raman, UV-Vis, fluorescence, and NMR spectroscopy, along with computational chemistry and mathematical modeling. The project is utilizing recent developments in lecture and laboratory pedagogies of active, contextualized learning to assist students in developing a deeper appreciation for, and understanding of, physical chemistry and its relationship to other scientific disciplines. Modular spectrophotometry equipment is adding capabilities in Raman, surfaced-enhanced Raman, time-resolved fluorescence, and chemiluminescence to the Physical Chemistry Laboratories. The Gaussian suite of programs is being used for molecular modeling and Mathematica is being used for the mathematical modeling.

Easily adaptable materials, relying on relatively low cost instrumentation, are being developed and made available to the community at large through both common dissemination pathways and via multiple digital repositories. The materials are being tested utilizing the diverse student populations at the collaborating schools and in both semester and trimester settings. Guided by the intended student learning outcomes for each module, the assessment and evaluation activity is using both empirical and qualitative approaches and is being consistently administered at both intervention sites. These data are being compared to similar data collected prior to the implementation of the intervention in order to establish how well the project is meeting its goals for improving student learning outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of this grant, a collaborative project between Knox College and Grinnell College, we developed four spectroscopy based laboratories to be used in the physical chemistry curriculum.  The primary project goal was to develop adaptable laboratory and curricular materials for physical chemistry that introduce students to spectroscopic and computational techniques using an innovative, context-rich pedagogical approach. Specific objectives included:

1) introduce modular spectroscopic instrumentation and computational techniques into the physical chemistry curriculum

2) to help students develop skills that will let them apply their knowledge of physical chemistry concepts to interdisciplinary applications

3) to assess the impact of contextualized laboratory experimentation on student learning, comprehension, and attitudes.

4) to disseminate the developed materials and assessment results to the greater physical chemistry community.

 

Products

We have developed four laboratories using spectroscopic equipment.   Three of the laboratories also introduce students to computational chemistry, and one uses Mathcad or Mathematica for numerical modeling.  For three of the laboratories we have also written updated modules (guided readings of a paper from the literature highlighting interdisciplinary applications of the techniques).  For the 4th laboratory, we used an existing Physical Chemistry with a Purpose Module. When developing modules we focused on creating materials that highlighted accomplishments from female and underrepresented scientists.  We have developed materials for both students and instructors to facilitate adoption of this material we are currently working on making all material meet accessibility guidelines. 

 

Assessment

Our primary assessment has included a survey and a detailed analysis of student work.  Our results demonstrate that addition of the coupled module and new laboratory increases both student learning and student ability to articulate how physical chemistry connects to other fields.

 

Dissemination:

We have presented our work at numerous meetings, including national and regional meetings of the American Society as well as the BCCE.  We also attended a POGIL physical chemistry laboratory workshop and spoke briefly about our project there.  We are planning a hands-on workshop for physical chemistry laboratory instructors at the upcoming BCCE meeting in August 2016.
